div.p: Most Reverend Father in Christ, you have already long since understood from your own sources what has been done here and what the hope is; therefore, there is no need for me to trouble you with more details. If your friends write to ours amicably, there is good hope; if harshly and bitterly, I see none at all. If I were with you, you would hear what has exasperated our people. - I wish to know from you what is happening in Germany. There are those who assert that the city of Metz is to be invaded; but I scarcely believe it. - I am going to the baths at Fideris; the utmost necessity for my health compels me; if I did not carry my cares with me from home, perhaps I would bathe more effectively. If you write anything, send it to my people; there are daily those who carry it there. I am sending my son to Zürich; he has made moderate progress in his studies. Here the school is not at all well-attended and is frequently interrupted; I feared he might be neglected. If he comes to you, I ask you to encourage him towards piety. Things instilled by such great men as you are more firmly retained. - The plague does not indeed progress here; but almost wherever it strikes a house, it empties it. Another son of Philipp has also died. I commend myself to your prayers.
Chur, 30th of June, in the year 1566.
To the most distinguished man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and most reverend father in Christ. In Zürich.
